newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight rises to 8.8 pct on market tightness.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight rises to 8.8 pct on market tightness.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate rose to 8.80 percent on Thursday, helped by market tightness and month-end ringgit demand, dealers said.
It closed at 8.50/70 percent on Wednesday.
"A Bank Negara agent was earlier lending at 8.8 percent but we do not know if it was on behalf of the central bank," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.
Bank Negara has been injecting fresh funds into the market for the past two weeks to help eased the shortage, dealers said.
Recent heavy buying of the ringgit by the central bank to defend the currency from speculative attack had caused a liquidity squeeze.
But despite the central bank lending, the market was too short to prevent a spike up in rates, dealers said.
Dealers said with the market still short of funds, only the central bank could determine where rates are heading.
"At the moment, nobody knows what Bank Negara wants to do," another dealer said.
Earlier, one- and two-week money were at 8.70/80 percent against 8.50/70 percent on Wednesday.
One-month money was at 8.60/70 percent from 8.50 percent, and three-month was at 8.45/50 percent against 8.30 percent.
Dealers said rates might come off slightly on Friday due to maturity of Bank Negara bills worth 500 million ringgit.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were down across the board to reflect firmer interbank rates.
At 0830 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was down five points to 92.18, or an implied yield of 7.82 percent.
The December contract fell two to 92.46, or 7.54 percent while March 1998 was down one to 92.56, or 7.44 percent.
